bestBHT.bht: Paul thought it was inappropriate to take John Mark with them on their journey because he had previously withdrawn from them in Pamphylia and had not gone with them to the work. His departure was not authorized by the Apostles, and Paul did not trust him to persevere in the toils and perils they would face. This decision by Paul was significant, as it led to a parting between him and Barnabas, both of whom had different opinions and could not reconcile their differences.

Henry Alford: Paul thought proper, (as to) one who had fallen off from them from Pamphylia, and had not gone with them to the work, not to take with them that man."
We may well believe that St. Paul’s own mouth gave originally the character to the sentence.
It hence is evident that his departure was not by the authority of the Apostles.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But Paul thought not good to take him with them who departed from them..."
...the word is stronger than this—'who stood aloof' or 'turned away' from them.
The allusion is to what is recorded in Acts 13:13.
Albert Barnes: But Paul thought not good - Did not think it proper. Because he could not confide in his perseverance with them in the toils and perils of their journey.

Who departed from them ... - Acts 13:13. Why he did this is not known. It was evidently, however, for some cause which Paul did not consider satisfactory, and which, in his view, disqualified him from being their attendant again.
To the work - Of preaching the gospel.
Marvin Vincent: Him [τουτον] . Lit., that one. It marks him very strongly, and is an emphatic position at the end of the sentence.
Departed [αποσταντα] . Rev., withdrew. It furnishes the derivation of our word apostatize.
Philip Schaff: We may well believe that Paul’s own mouth gave originally the character to this sentence.
The strict and truthful accuracy of the writer of these ‘Acts’ is shown by his faithful record of the parting between the two friends Barnabas and Paul.
Both those noble men seemed to have erred the one perhaps too harsh, the other too forgiving; neither chose to yield his opinion, and so they parted.
Archibald T. Robertson: But Paul kept on deeming it wise not to be taking along with them this one.
Paul had a definite reason for his view describing John Mark as 'him who withdrew from them from Pamphylia', the one who stood off from, apostatized from.
Paul declined to repeat the experiment with Mark.
John Gill: But Paul thought not good to take him with them... He did not think him worthy, or a fit and proper person to go with them.

His reasons were as follow: who departed from them from Pamphylia... he was very blameworthy, and on account of it very undeserving, at least at present, of being a companion of theirs in their travels.
John deserted them; and which the apostle resented, he having, as yet, not given any evidence of his sense of his evil, and of his repentance for it, to his satisfaction.
John Wesley: Paul thought it not right... to trust him again, who had deserted them before.
Who had shrunk from the labour and danger of converting those they were now going to confirm.
